title: What is the set of values for x for which (x-1) (x+2) <18? - Quora
tags: Middle and High School Math Homework Question

response.answer_text: [math](x - 1)(x+2)<18[/math] [math]x^2+2x - x - 2 < 18[/math] [math]x^2+x - 2 < 18[/math] [math]x^2+x - 2 - 18<0[/math] [math]x^2+x - 20<0[/math] Our function is [math]f(x)=x^2+x - 20[/math]. We want the values such that [math]f(x)[/math] is negative, that is, [math]f(x)<0[/math]. [math]x^2+x - 20<0[/math] We need the roots of the function. [math]x^2+x - 20=0[/math] Using Bhaskara Method, we have [math]\Delta=1^2 - 4(1)( - 20)=1+80=81[/math] [math]\Longrightarrow\sqrt{\Delta}=9[/math] Roots: [math]x=\dfrac{ - 1 - 9}{2}=\dfrac{ - 10}{2} = - 5[/math] [math]x_2=\dfrac{ - 1 + 9}{2}=\dfrac{8}{2}=4[/math] Remember that, if we have a quadratic function [math]f(x)=ax^2+bx+c[/math], the function has a minimum if [math]a>0[/math], and the function has a maximum if [math]a<0[/math]. So, our function has a minimum. It means that our function is negative when [math]- 5<x<4[/math]. In the WolframAlpha, you can check it! (x-1)(x+2)<18 - Wolfram|Alpha P.S.: In this link, you need write “<18″, because shows only “(x-1)(x+2)”.

(x-1)(x+2)<18 is equivalent to (x+5)(x-4)<0 [multiply out and combine all terms on the left side.] If x < -5, both (x+5) and (x-4) are negative, so their product will be positive. So no x value less than -5 will satisfy (x-1)(x+2)<18. If x > 4, then both (x+5) and (x-4) are positive and again their product will be positive. So no x value greater than 4 will satisfy (x-1)(x+2)<18. That leaves values of x between -5 and 4. For those values of x, (x-5) is positive and (x-4) is negative and their product will be negative. So the solutions are all x values for which -5<x<4.
